docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson column offers recipes for young, spring vegetables; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: TENDER young vegetables, picked fresh from the garden in spring, make you forget about the damp days of winter. ''For best results, you should ideally go out into your vegetable garden and pick what you need,'' Roger Verge, the celebrated Provencal chef, said, ''either at dawn or after the sun has set. But if you can get up early and visit a local farmer's market first thing in the morning, you should be able to get wonderfully fresh vegetables.'' He makes a fricassee of baby carrots, turnips and new potatoes cooked with fresh small peas under a layer of spring lettuces. This dish is so good it stands on its own. Baby artichokes are also delicious in spring, sauteed with fennel and young, peeled fava beans and sprinkled with leaves of tarragon (this goes very well with roast chicken).

headline.main: Flavors of Spring From a Cornucopia of Young Vegetables

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant article on cooking with spring herbs; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT has felt like spring for months and, finally, the season has arrived. And the appetite is more than ready for food that is richly herbaceous yet sturdy enough to satisfy when a chill lingers in the air. Long before bunches of fresh basil or mint are abundant in the market, the cook can rely on staples like parsley, watercress and scallions to provide verdant, springtime freshness to an array of dishes. Here are recipes along these lines, for a green soup with scallops, roast chicken with a peppery watercress sauce and a potato gratin sharpened with scallions.

headline.main: Fresh Parsley, Watercress and Scallions Add Greenery to Dishes

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson column on use of lentils in variety of dishes; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE lentil, wrote the French gastronome Robert J. Courtine, ''brings with it the whiff of the boarding school and the barracks,'' and, he added, ''not to say the prison.'' The true gourmet revels in it, he also said, ''at every moment of the meal, from lentil soup to lentil salad.'' Now that the humble potato can cost as much as $6 a pound, the price of lentils -- around 50 cents a pound --makes them hard to pass up. Lentils have always been cheap and over the centuries have been dismissed as food for the poor. But now they are showing up on the menus of the fanciest restaurants, served as a foil for rich meats like braised lamb or ham, or with a fatty fish like salmon.

headline.main: Hail the Humble Lentil: To Enrich Soup or Meat and Fish

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson column offers tips on preparing and cooking radicchio; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is hard to believe that just a decade ago, unless they had been to Italy, few Americans knew what radicchio was. Now this red-leafed chicory is widely available, a staple in ready-made supermarket salad mixes as well as sold on its own. I like it well enough raw, but I much prefer it cooked. It loses its pretty autumnal red color, but it becomes sweeter, mellower and more intense in flavor.

headline.main: Cooked Radicchio Gets Sweeter When It Loses Its Autumn Hue

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill article on cooking with parsley; recipes; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Like salt, parsley is a seasoning that orchestrates other flavors. So deftly does it do its job that it is usually taken for granted. This lack of praise is not reflected in the medical folklore, where parsley is touted as an effective cure for rheumatism, swelling and lethargy. The Romans used parsley to stimulate circulation and appetite. And in recent years, the sales of parsley capsules have increased right along with the wholesale consumption of garlic.

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant column (Food) describes ways to prepare and serve swordfish; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CONSIDER a meaty fish like swordfish to be a blank slate. It has nice flavor, to be sure, but it adapts extremely well to various seasonings. Here are three international personalities suitable for grilled swordfish. For each recipe the fish first is marinated for a couple of hours in a mixture of ingredients. Similar ingredients are combined to provide a sauce to complement the grilled fish.

headline.main: For International Cooks, a Colorful Canvas From a Bland Fish

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson article on preparing desserts with apricots; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE season for apricots is depressingly short. But from now through the end of next month they will be available in the markets, fresh, ripe and tender, with a flavor that intensifies when they cook. I like to bake apricots in a light syrup flavored with vanilla and kirsch and serve them with creme fraiche on the side. Baked apricots will keep for a week in the refrigerator, provided they are well coated with their syrup. (If not, their skins darken; this does not affect their taste, but it does not look very appetizing).

headline.main: Their Flavor Heightened by Cooking, Apricots Star as a Dessert

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill column gives recipes for chilled soups; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of confusion, the summer we ate cold soup, I learned the difference between human energy and turbopower. The differences are not readily apparent. A food mill operated by hand will produce a strained puree that retains texture, even if the texture is perceptible only to the human tongue. When you apply electricity to the same centrifugal principle -- that is, when you plug in the blender or food processor -- you get an unstrained puree that has been traumatized into a smooth, homogeneous whole.
